alert.note: Alert for Robeson (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 02 at 8:41PM EDT until September 04 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Marion, Dillon and Horry Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Little Pee Dee River At Galivants Ferry affecting Marion and Horry Counties. Waccamaw River At Conway affecting Horry County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Little Pee Dee River...including Galivants Ferry...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Waccamaw River...including Aiw At old Hwy 544 At Socastee, Conway, Above Conway, Freeland, Longs...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL MONDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Lumber River near Lumberton. * WHEN...Until Monday evening. * IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Low land flooding will occur along the river. The flood waters may affect some residential property as water backs up into the drainage ditches in the city. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:50 PM EDT Saturday the stage was 13.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage Monday morning and continue falling to 12.2 feet Thursday evening. - Flood stage is 13.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by Sunday afternoon.
